channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: London Theater Collapse Causes Injuries During Sold-Out Show
item.description: At least seven people were seriously hurt and another 81 lightly injured, according to fire and medical officials, when the ceiling of a tall Edwardian theater collapsed Thursday night during a sold-out performance.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: An injured woman was helped by emergency workers outside of the Apollo Theater.

item.title: I.M.F. Scolds Ukraine Plan For Economy
item.description: Days after Russia agreed to lend Ukraine $15 billion, the International Monetary Fund said that without comprehensive macroeconomic reforms the money would essentially be thrown into a black hole.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Hagel Criticizes Chinese Navy, Citing Near Miss
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said the Chinese Navy acted irresponsibly in allowing a warship to pass perilously close to an American warship.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey take questions from reporters at the Pentagon in Washington, Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Ambassador Visits Central African Republic Amid Bloodshed
item.description: The American ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, landed in the besieged capital of the Central African Republic on Thursday with a message: The United States is watching.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, met with Archbishop Dieudonne Nzapala Inga, second left, and Imam Oumar Kobine Layama, second right, on Thursday in Bangui.

item.title: The Lede: Ceiling at Theater in London Collapses on Audience
item.description: Videos of eyewitnesses from outside the Apollo Theater, where dozens of people were injured after part of the ceiling collapsed onto the audience during a performance.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Russian Court Convicts Gay-Rights Advocate
item.description: Dmitri Isakov faces a fine of about $120 for violating Russia’s law against “gay propaganda” by holding a sign that said violence against gays “is criminal.”
item.dc:creator: By NOAH SNEIDER

item.title: Putin, Secure in Power, Says He May Free Jailed Rival
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, could soon be freed from prison, a reversal many saw as an attempt to quiet critics before the Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: The arrest ten years ago of Mr. Khodorkovsky, seen in 2010, signaled an authoritarian turn for Mr. Putin.

item.title: In Rodman’s Ties to North Korea, Holy and Business Forces
item.description: How Dennis Rodman and Paddy Power came to know each other is connected to the online betting company’s acceptance of wagers on almost anything.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Dennis Rodman was greeted by Song Kwang-ho, the vice chairman of North Korea's Olympic Committee, at Pyongyang on Thursday.

item.title: Trial of Kenyan President May Be Collapsing
item.description: The prosecution of Kenya’s president, Uhuru Kenyatta, for crimes against humanity was dealt a severe blow when the prosecutor said she lacked sufficient evidence to proceed.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Listening Post: On Iran and Syria, Diplomatic Tests Intertwine
item.description: The United States has strictly segregated the Iranian nuclear talks from the diplomatic efforts to end the bloodshed in Syria, but success or failure in each could heavily influence the other.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Immigration Remakes and Sustains New York, Report Finds
item.description: A new report says the city’s immigrant population has reached a high of 3.1 million, led by a tremendous growth in the Chinese population.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: Xian Hua Li, in center, was among a group of immigrants granted American citizenship on Wednesday. He is part of the surging population of Chinese-born immigrants living in New York City, now totaling 350,200 people.

item.title: 2 Found Guilty in Grisly Killing of British Soldier
item.description: The British-born converts to Islam who ran over a soldier and hacked him with knives and a meat cleaver face life in prison.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Suicide Bombers Attack Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq
item.description: Lone attackers have evaded controls, using concealed bombs as they infiltrated the crowds of pilgrims or targeting travelers in their vehicles en route to the shrines.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Prosecutor Says Kate Middleton’s Phone Was Hacked
item.description: The disclosure came in a high profile trial into Britain’s phone hacking scandal.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Pakistani Army Kills 23 Suspected of Being Militants
item.description: The shelling and raids appeared to be in retaliation for a suicide bombing on Wednesday that killed at least five soldiers in North Waziristan.
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: India Ink: The Domestic Help’s Views in Debate over Diplomat’s Arrest
item.description: Three domestic helpers in Delhi weigh in on the case of Devyani Khobragade, the Indian deputy consul general in New York, who was charged with underpaying her housekeeper.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on Thursday protesting the alleged mistreatment of Indian diplomat Devyani Khobragade by U.S. government authorities.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 19
item.description: Indian cricketer Mohammed Shami in action against South Africa at the Wanderers Stadium in Johannesburg.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: U.N. Panel Cites ‘Terror’ Campaign Against Syrian Civilians
item.description: The Syrian government has orchestrated a policy of forced disappearances that amounts to a crime against humanity, United Nations investigators said in a report.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Letter From Europe: Drawn Into the Tangle of Syria’s War
item.description: The deaths of two Britons shows how the Syrian war has drawn outsiders into its maw only to destroy them, as the region has done on many previous occasions.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Britain to Evacuate Its Citizens From South Sudan
item.description: Britain said it had dispatched an airplane to evacuate British nationals as clashes were reported to have spread in South Sudan following claims of an attempted coup.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.S. Prosecutor Defends Charges Against Indian Diplomat
item.description: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, offered a robust defense of the decision to arrest the diplomat, Devyani Khobragade, while India’s foreign minister on Thursday called for the case to be dropped.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Tokyo’s Governor Resigns Amid Scandal
item.description: Naoki Inose had admitted to receiving more than half a million dollars during an election, but had said that it was a personal loan.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Putin Says Deal With Ukraine Was a Good-Will Gesture
item.description: At a wide-ranging news conference in Moscow, the Russian president said, “We should support our sister nation when in dire straits.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traditionally holds a large news conference in December.

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographing Favela Funk
item.description: Before he even heard it, Vincent Rosenblatt felt the carioca funk music pumping out from the favelas near his home, rattling his windows and stirring his resolve to photograph the favela dance scene.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Lacraia (or Centipede), a dancer famed for her duo work with M.C. Serginho, from the favela Jacarézinho, applied makeup before entering the stage at the club Nova Show in São Gonçalo.

item.title: South Korean Cyberwarfare Unit Accused of Political Meddling
item.description: Military investigators asked prosecutors to indict 11 officials on charges of violating a law that bans public servants from meddling in politics.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
